response_parsed.title: Combining Turtle and Typing for Production Code in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer demonstrates the integration of Turtle graphics and Type Hints in Python 3.12+, enhancing the readability, maintainability, and productivity of your code.
key_points: Utilize type hints to improve code clarity and reduce errors
Use the Turtle library for graphics and animations
Combine both to create robust and well-structured production code

code_examples.code:
from turtle import Turtle, Screen
from typing import Callable

def draw_square(t: Turtle, side_length: int) -> None:
    for _ in range(4):
        t.forward(side_length)
        t.right(90)

screen = Screen()
screen.bgcolor('white')

t = Turtle(visible=False)
t.penup()

# Move the turtle to the center of the screen
screen.setup(width=640, height=640)
screen.center(*screen.screensize())

t.goto(0, -240)

# Draw a square with side_length = 100
draw_square(t, 100)

screen.exitonclick()

version_notes: This code is designed for Python 3.12+ and requires the Turtle library
Python 3.5 introduced type hints, but they are optional, and full support came in Python 3.7
caveats: Remember to import the necessary modules (Turtle and typing) at the start of your code
Type hints don't affect the runtime behavior but improve the readability of your code
